Okay, I need to summarize this document about shopping directories in 3-5 sentences. Let me start by reading through the content carefully.

The document explains what an online shopping directory is, comparing it to traditional directories and other similar services. It mentions that these directories organize ecommerce sites by category, unlike comparison shopping sites which focus on product comparisons and prices. There's also a distinction between directories and online marketplaces like Amazon. Then there's a section on variations, including coupon sites. The history part talks about how free directories like the Open Directory Project declined with the rise of Google, and now there's a push to reinvent shopping directories. The business models include listing fees, affiliate programs, and ads.

So the main points are: definition of shopping directories, differences from comparison sites and marketplaces, variations like coupon sites, historical context with the shift to search engines, and current business models. I need to condense this into a concise summary. Make sure to highlight the key concepts without getting too detailed. Check for any specific examples mentioned, but maybe just mention them briefly. Avoid jargon where possible. Ensure each sentence covers a distinct aspect. Let me try to structure it step by step.
</think>

An online shopping directory is a categorized web platform that aggregates ecommerce sites, helping users locate online retailers by product type, distinct from comparison shopping sites (which focus on price comparisons) and marketplaces (which host third-party sellers under their brand). It evolved from traditional directories but declined with the rise of search engines like Google, which now dominate online shopping searches, though new startups aim to revitalize their relevance. Variations include coupon and deal sites, which prioritize discounts but face merchant skepticism, while business models rely on listing fees, affiliate commissions, and advertising. The document highlights the shift from directory-based shopping to search-driven commerce and ongoing efforts to adapt directories to modern ecommerce needs.

Chunk:

[S1] Shopping directory


# Shopping directory



An online **shopping directory** is a "Yellow Pages-Style" web directory that specializes in ecommerce sites (which are websites that sell products or services). [S2] Inspired by the organizational structure used in traditional shopping mall directories, online shopping directories organize ecommerce sites by their category and subcategory of goods sold. [S3] Without the constraints related to shopping at a physical mall (e.g. [S4] distance, location, hours of operation, access to transportation), an online shopping directory serves to aggregate all ecommerce sites in one centralized location in order to help a user decide where to shop online. [S5] ## Variations

A shopping directory is different from a comparison shopping website (which is also referred to as a comparison shopping engine or a price comparison shopping site). [S6] While comparison shopping websites present product listings, by category, so a user can compare pricing on same and/or similar products, a shopping directory does not provide product comparison, review or sale. [S7] Examples of comparison shopping websites include: Google Shopping, Shopping.com, Shopzilla, TheFind.com

A shopping directory is different from an online marketplace. [S8] Marketplaces sell products and/or services that are aggregated from various ecommerce sellers but sold under the branding and infrastructure of the named marketplace itself. [S9] Examples of online marketplaces include: Amazon, Etsy and eBay. [S10] A specialized form of a shopping directory is a coupon, daily deal and/or promotional savings site. [S11] Coupon sites provide a niche web directory centered on deal aggregation by listing only ecommerce sites that offer additional savings to the user. [S12] Coupon sites are very popular with users but often are viewed negatively by merchants. [S13] Examples of coupon sites include: Retailmenot, Coupons.com, Groupon


## History

Free directories such as the Open Directory Project, often updated by volunteers, lost their prominence and relevancy in today's search-driven internet. [S14] Before the increased popularity of the Google search engine, shopping directories, such as that found at the Yahoo! [S15] Directory or the PayPal Shopping Directory, played a prominent role in users' online shopping habits and behavior. [S16] As Google gained dominance, users adapted their shopping search behavior to the new system. [S17] Most search engines took over the role traditionally filled by shopping directories. [S18] Recently, criticisms have emerged over the limits of using search engines such as Google and Bing for use in the ecommerce cycle. [S19] The dominance of the SEO structure in search makes competition fierce among merchants as they struggle for positioning on the Google search results pages. [S20] New methodologies for shopping directories are emerging as startups look to bridge the gap between ecommerce and search. [S21] As ecommerce continues to grow, startup companies are reinvisioning the shopping directory to make it more relevant to the growing needs of online shoppers. [S22] ## Business model

* Charging a one-time and/or recurring listing fee to the ecommerce site
* Use of affiliate programs of the listed ecommerce sites to earn commissions on referrals
* Advertising in the directory itself, such as banner ads, contextual ads like Google AdSense or some form of sponsored listings (usually pay per click based)
* Combination of above

An online **shopping directory** is a "Yellow Pages-Style" web directory that specializes in ecommerce sites (which are websites that sell products or services). [S2] Inspired by the organizational structure used in traditional shopping mall directories, online shopping directories organize ecommerce sites by their category and subcategory of goods sold. [S3] Without the constraints related to shopping at a physical mall (e.g. [S4] distance, location, hours of operation, access to transportation), an online shopping directory serves to aggregate all ecommerce sites in one centralized location in order to help a user decide where to shop online. [S5] ## Variations

A shopping directory is different from a comparison shopping website (which is also referred to as a comparison shopping engine or a price comparison shopping site). [S6] While comparison shopping websites present product listings, by category, so a user can compare pricing on same and/or similar products, a shopping directory does not provide product comparison, review or sale. [S7] Examples of comparison shopping websites include: Google Shopping, Shopping.com, Shopzilla, TheFind.com

A shopping directory is different from an online marketplace. [S8] Marketplaces sell products and/or services that are aggregated from various ecommerce sellers but sold under the branding and infrastructure of the named marketplace itself. [S9] Examples of online marketplaces include: Amazon, Etsy and eBay. [S10] A specialized form of a shopping directory is a coupon, daily deal and/or promotional savings site. [S11] Coupon sites provide a niche web directory centered on deal aggregation by listing only ecommerce sites that offer additional savings to the user. [S12] Coupon sites are very popular with users but often are viewed negatively by merchants. [S13] Examples of coupon sites include: Retailmenot, Coupons.com, Groupon


## History

Free directories such as the Open Directory Project, often updated by volunteers, lost their prominence and relevancy in today's search-driven internet. [S14] Before the increased popularity of the Google search engine, shopping directories, such as that found at the Yahoo! [S15] Directory or the PayPal Shopping Directory, played a prominent role in users' online shopping habits and behavior. [S16] As Google gained dominance, users adapted their shopping search behavior to the new system. [S17] Most search engines took over the role traditionally filled by shopping directories. [S18] Recently, criticisms have emerged over the limits of using search engines such as Google and Bing for use in the ecommerce cycle. [S19] The dominance of the SEO structure in search makes competition fierce among merchants as they struggle for positioning on the Google search results pages. [S20] New methodologies for shopping directories are emerging as startups look to bridge the gap between ecommerce and search. [S21] As ecommerce continues to grow, startup companies are reinvisioning the shopping directory to make it more relevant to the growing needs of online shoppers. [S22] ## Business model

* Charging a one-time and/or recurring listing fee to the ecommerce site
* Use of affiliate programs of the listed ecommerce sites to earn commissions on referrals
* Advertising in the directory itself, such as banner ads, contextual ads like Google AdSense or some form of sponsored listings (usually pay per click based)
* Combination of above

Chunk:

[S1] Shopping directory


# Shopping directory



An online **shopping directory** is a "Yellow Pages-Style" web directory that specializes in ecommerce sites (which are websites that sell products or services). [S2] Inspired by the organizational structure used in traditional shopping mall directories, online shopping directories organize ecommerce sites by their category and subcategory of goods sold. [S3] Without the constraints related to shopping at a physical mall (e.g. [S4] distance, location, hours of operation, access to transportation), an online shopping directory serves to aggregate all ecommerce sites in one centralized location in order to help a user decide where to shop online. [S5] ## Variations

A shopping directory is different from a comparison shopping website (which is also referred to as a comparison shopping engine or a price comparison shopping site). [S6] While comparison shopping websites present product listings, by category, so a user can compare pricing on same and/or similar products, a shopping directory does not provide product comparison, review or sale. [S7] Examples of comparison shopping websites include: Google Shopping, Shopping.com, Shopzilla, TheFind.com

A shopping directory is different from an online marketplace. [S8] Marketplaces sell products and/or services that are aggregated from various ecommerce sellers but sold under the branding and infrastructure of the named marketplace itself. [S9] Examples of online marketplaces include: Amazon, Etsy and eBay. [S10] A specialized form of a shopping directory is a coupon, daily deal and/or promotional savings site. [S11] Coupon sites provide a niche web directory centered on deal aggregation by listing only ecommerce sites that offer additional savings to the user. [S12] Coupon sites are very popular with users but often are viewed negatively by merchants. [S13] Examples of coupon sites include: Retailmenot, Coupons.com, Groupon


## History

Free directories such as the Open Directory Project, often updated by volunteers, lost their prominence and relevancy in today's search-driven internet. [S14] Before the increased popularity of the Google search engine, shopping directories, such as that found at the Yahoo! [S15] Directory or the PayPal Shopping Directory, played a prominent role in users' online shopping habits and behavior. [S16] As Google gained dominance, users adapted their shopping search behavior to the new system. [S17] Most search engines took over the role traditionally filled by shopping directories. [S18] Recently, criticisms have emerged over the limits of using search engines such as Google and Bing for use in the ecommerce cycle. [S19] The dominance of the SEO structure in search makes competition fierce among merchants as they struggle for positioning on the Google search results pages. [S20] New methodologies for shopping directories are emerging as startups look to bridge the gap between ecommerce and search. [S21] As ecommerce continues to grow, startup companies are reinvisioning the shopping directory to make it more relevant to the growing needs of online shoppers. [S22] ## Business model

* Charging a one-time and/or recurring listing fee to the ecommerce site
* Use of affiliate programs of the listed ecommerce sites to earn commissions on referrals
* Advertising in the directory itself, such as banner ads, contextual ads like Google AdSense or some form of sponsored listings (usually pay per click based)
* Combination of above

[S5] ## Variations

A shopping directory is different from a comparison shopping website (which is also referred to as a comparison shopping engine or a price comparison shopping site). [S6] While comparison shopping websites present product listings, by category, so a user can compare pricing on same and/or similar products, a shopping directory does not provide product comparison, review or sale. [S7] Examples of comparison shopping websites include: Google Shopping, Shopping.com, Shopzilla, TheFind.com

A shopping directory is different from an online marketplace. [S8] Marketplaces sell products and/or services that are aggregated from various ecommerce sellers but sold under the branding and infrastructure of the named marketplace itself. [S9] Examples of online marketplaces include: Amazon, Etsy and eBay. [S10] A specialized form of a shopping directory is a coupon, daily deal and/or promotional savings site. [S11] Coupon sites provide a niche web directory centered on deal aggregation by listing only ecommerce sites that offer additional savings to the user. [S12] Coupon sites are very popular with users but often are viewed negatively by merchants. [S13] Examples of coupon sites include: Retailmenot, Coupons.com, Groupon


## History

Free directories such as the Open Directory Project, often updated by volunteers, lost their prominence and relevancy in today's search-driven internet. [S14] Before the increased popularity of the Google search engine, shopping directories, such as that found at the Yahoo! [S15] Directory or the PayPal Shopping Directory, played a prominent role in users' online shopping habits and behavior. [S16] As Google gained dominance, users adapted their shopping search behavior to the new system. [S17] Most search engines took over the role traditionally filled by shopping directories. [S18] Recently, criticisms have emerged over the limits of using search engines such as Google and Bing for use in the ecommerce cycle. [S19] The dominance of the SEO structure in search makes competition fierce among merchants as they struggle for positioning on the Google search results pages. [S20] New methodologies for shopping directories are emerging as startups look to bridge the gap between ecommerce and search. [S21] As ecommerce continues to grow, startup companies are reinvisioning the shopping directory to make it more relevant to the growing needs of online shoppers. [S22] ## Business model

* Charging a one-time and/or recurring listing fee to the ecommerce site
* Use of affiliate programs of the listed ecommerce sites to earn commissions on referrals
* Advertising in the directory itself, such as banner ads, contextual ads like Google AdSense or some form of sponsored listings (usually pay per click based)
* Combination of above
